chapter.title: Hosts
chapter.para: The host specific elements which may be contained in the host description are as follows:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: One of DOWN, ERROR, INITIALIZING, INSTALLING, INSTALL_FAILED, MAINTENANCE, NON_OPERATIONAL, NON_RESPONSIVE, PENDING_APPROVAL, PREPARING_FOR_MAINTENANCE, PROBLEMATIC, REBOOT, UNASSIGNED or UP
The IP address or hostname of the host
The cluster that includes this host
The listen port of the VDSM daemon running on this host
The root password of this host, by convention only included in the client-provided host representation on creation
The compatibility level of the host (see )
true if the host is the storage pool manager (SPM)
Fencing options for host power management. (see )
true if transparent hugepages is enabled. (see )
true if Kernel SamePage Merging (KSM) is enabled. Is disabled if transparent_hugepages is enabled. (see )

chapter.para: When creating a new host, the name, address and root_password elements are required. The root_password element is by convention only included in the client-provided initial representation (i.e. is not reported in the representations returned from subsequent GETs and UPDATEs). Only the name element may be updated post-creation.
There are four possible actions for hosts - install, approve, activate and deactivate.

section.title: Network Interfaces
section.para: A host's physical network interfaces are represented by a collection obtained via link rel="nics" in the host's representation.
Each network interface is represented by a host_nic element which may contain the following properties:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: The name of the host network interface, e.g. eth0

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

row.entry: A reference to the network, if any, that the interface is attached to

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

row.entry: The MAC address of the interface
The IP level configuration of the interface
The VLAN which this interface represents, if any
A list of slave host_nic elements, if this is a bonded interface

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

row.entry: A reference to the master bonded interface, if this is a slave interface

section.para: For example:
section.screen: <host_nic id="e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8"> <name>bond0</name> <host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"/> <network id="e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85" href="/rhevm-api/networks/e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85"/> <mac address="D6:76:F1:3A:AF:74"/> <ip address="192.168.0.128" netmask="255.255.255.0" gateway="192.168.0.1"/> <slaves> <host_nic id="eb14e154-5e73-4f7f-bf6b-7f52609d94ec" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/eb14e154-5e73-4f7f-bf6b-7f52609d94ec"/> <host_nic id="6aede5ca-4c54-4b37-a81b-c0d6b53558ea" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/6aede5ca-4c54-4b37-a81b-c0d6b53558ea"/> </slaves> <actions> <link rel="attach" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8/attach"/> <link rel="detach" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8/detach"/> </actions> </host_nic>

note.para: With the exception of bonded interfaces (see ), network interfaces are read-only. Interfaces cannot be added, updated or removed.

section.title: Bonded Interfaces
section.para: A bonded interface is represented by a host_nic with a slaves element containing a host_nic reference for each of the interfaces enslaved to the bond. Each slave host_nic contains a link rel="master" reference back to the bonded interface.
A new bond may be created by POSTing a host_nic describing which interfaces should be enslaved. For example:
section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<host_nic> <name>bond4</name> <network id="e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85"/> <slaves> <host_nic id="eb14e154-5e73-4f7f-bf6b-7f52609d94ec"/> <host_nic id="6aede5ca-4c54-4b37-a81b-c0d6b53558ea"/> </slaves> </host_nic>
section.para: The name, network and slave host_nic elements are required when creating a new bonded interface. The network and slave host_nics may be identified by id or name.

note.para: bond0, bond1, bond2, bond3 and bond4 are the only valid names for a bonded interface.

section.para: Like other resources, a bonded interface may be deleted by issuing a DELETE request to its URI.

warning.para: Changes to bonded interface configuration must be explicitly committed. See .

section.title: Attach Action
section.para: A host network interface may be attached to a network, indicating that the given network is accessible over the interface. The network may be identified by id or name.

warning.para: This networking configuration change must be explicitly committed. See .

section.title: Detach Action
section.para: Detach an interface from a network. The network may be identified by id or name.

warning.para: This networking configuration change must be explicitly committed. See .

section.title: iSCSI and FCP Storage
section.para: The collection referenced by link rel="storage" describes the iSCSI and FCP storage available on the host. This storage may be used to create storage domains, as described in .
Each storage description in the collection represents either a SCSI LUN or an LVM volume group. A logical_unit representation may contain:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: An opaque identifier for the logical unit
The address of the iSCSI portal containing the LUN, in the case of iSCSI
The port number of the iSCSI portal
A CHAP user name for logging into an iSCSI target
A CHAP password for logging into an iSCSI target

section.para: A volume_group representation may contain:

row.entry: An opaque identifier for the volume group
Details of any SCSI LUNs on which the volume group is based

section.para: For example:
section.screen: <host_storage> <storage id="82fb123b-321e-40a1-9889-95dcd2654463" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/storage/82fb123b-321e-40a1-9889-95dcd2654463"> <name>LUN0</name> <type>iscsi</type> <logical_unit id="LUN0"> <address>mysan.example.com</address> <target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</target> </logical_unit> </storage> <storage id="f1d0ced5-d727-4217-8f2a-a514dff14bd5" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/storage/f1d0ced5-d727-4217-8f2a-a514dff14bd5"> <name>FooVG</name> <type>iscsi</type> <volume_group id="5432"> <name>FooVG</name> <logical_unit id="LUN1"> <address>mysan.example.com</address> <target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</target> </logical_unit> <logical_unit id="LUN2"> <address>mysan.example.com</address> <target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</target> </logical_unit> </volume_group> </storage> </host_storage>

section.title: Memory Management
section.para: The API provides two choices for a host's memory management:

listitem.para: Kernel SamePage Merging (KSM) - The host kernel reduces references to memory pages from multiple identical pages to a single page reference. This helps with optimization for memory density.
Transparent Hugepage support - Hugepage support expands the size of memory pages beyond the standard 4kB limit. This reduces memory consumption and increases host performance.

section.para: Kernel SamePage Merging (KSM) uses the ksm element, which is a read-only element:
Transparent Hugepage support uses the transparent_hugepages element and updates with a PUT request:
section.screen:
PUT /rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3 HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<host> <transparent_hugepages>true</transparent_hugepages> </host>
section.para: This also sets the status of ksm. For example, if transparent_hugepages is set to true, the API sets ksm to false:
If transparent_hugepages is set to false, the API sets ksm to true.

section.title: Install Action
section.para: Install VDSM and related software on the host. This requires the root password for the host to be supplied using the root_password element.

section.title: Activate Action
section.para: Activate the host, allowing it to be used for e.g. running VMs.

section.title: Deactivate Action
section.para: Deactivate the host, allowing maintenance tasks to be performed.

section.title: Commit Network Configuration Action
section.para: In order to persist a host network interface attach or detach, or persist the creation/deletion of a bonded interface, the network configuration must explicitly be committed.

warning.para: Networking configuration should only be committed after it has been established that host connectivity has not been lost as a result of the configuration changes. If host connectivity has been lost, the host should be rebooted and will automatically revert to the previous networking configuration.

section.title: iSCSI Discover Action
section.para: The iscsidiscover action enables an iSCSI portal to be query for its list of LUNs.
section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/iscsidiscover HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/xml Accept: application/xml
<action> <iscsi> <address>mysan.example.com</address> </iscsi> </action>
HTTP/1.1 202 Accept Content-Type: application/xml
<action id="e9126d04-0f74-4e1a-9139-13f11fcbb4ab" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/iscsidiscover/e9126d04-0f74-4e1a-9139-13f11fcbb4ab"> <iscsi_target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</iscsi_target> ... <action>

section.title: iSCSI Login Action
section.para: The iscsilogin action enables a host to login to an iSCSI target. Logging into a target makes the LUNs it contains available in the host_storage collection. See .
section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/iscsilogin HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/xml Accept: application/xml
<action> <iscsi> <address>mysan.example.com</address> <target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</target> <username>jimmy</username> <password>s3kr37</password> </iscsi> </action>

section.title: Power Management Configuration
section.para: A recommended feature of the Red Hat Virtualization platform is the option to fence a host with a power_management configuration. Certain sub-elements are required when configuring power_management.

row.entry: A list of valid fencing devices are available in system capabilities. See for more information.
Indicates whether power management configuration is enabled or disabled
The host name or IP address of the host
A valid user name for power management
A valid, robust password for power management
Fencing options for the selected type=

section.para: The options element requires a list of option sub-elements. Each option requires a name= and a type=. Certain options are only available for specific fencing types as defined in the system capabilities (see ) but can include options such as:

row.entry: Defines if SSH is enabled for power management device connection
Defines the port for power management device connection
Defines the slot to use, specifically when using a Blade server

section.para: A new host can include a power_management configuration when POSTing the host configuration. The power_management configuration can also update using PUT.
For example:
section.screen: <host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/rhevm-api/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"> <name>zig</name> ... <power_management type="ilo"> <enabled>true</enabled> <address>192.168.1.107</address> <username>admin</username> <password>p@55w0Rd!</password> <options> <option name="secure" value="true"/> <option name="port" value="54345"/> <option name="slot" value="3"/> </options> </power_management> ... </host>

section.title: Fencing Action
section.para: The fence action enables the system to fence a troublesome host and reduce power usage. See for details on configuring a fencing device for a host.
The fence_type is one of manual, start, status, stop, or restart.
